commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Benefactor with a limited number of grants?  (5)
2. Stealthy flier  (3)(7)
3. Mars comes third in it  (5)
4. Really involved  (6)
5. Sound made by a toaster?  (4)


GENIE
AIR MARSHAL
ANN√âE
ORNATE
TING
Crystal, I'm 73 and I haven't seen Mary Poppins either.

I quite enjoyed this one but:

1. There will be complaints that it‚Äôs too hard for a Monday (sorry folks!)

2, I have a slight qualm about SAYITDONTSPRAYIT - this is a cute rhyme but is this someone ever actually says?
Fun puzzle!  I grew up in the 1950‚Äôs and SAYITDONTSPRAYIT brought back fond memories of other such phrases that were popular back then. We thought we were so cool and clever.
A perfect Monday puzzle, in my opinion.
Welcome Crystal!

Very easy. 

Coincidence that we have 35D while the 49ers are playing the Eagles?

Interesting: the 28A clue is different in the online version and the Newspaper PDF version on the NYT site. I'm guessing the editors decided to shorten it after our guest columnist saw it to write the column, and it was changed for "the paper" but not online. Weird.

(I enjoyed the puzzle and the column.)
Get out of here with SHISO on a Monday

Not much to complain about, but I managed to find some anyway.  üòÅ

To my ear ORE and O'ER are not homophones, because O'ER has two syllables ('oh', followed by 'er'), whereas ORE only has one, the same as the actual homophones 'or' and 'oar'.
Thank you for this crossword puzzle on a cold winter night. I enjoyed this puzzle.
ill ILY
Someone last week mentioned not having seen Suejean commenting for a while. Hope you‚Äôre still following the puzzles and Wordplay, Suejean.

Crystal, welcome to the column, good summary‚Äîand what great advice to new solvers!

Nice Monday grid with an appealing theme.

TIL SHISO, nice word.

For some reason it didn‚Äôt bother me that there was no qualifier ‚Äúin the US‚Äù for ZEE, but the casual assumption that nouns generally precede verbs seemed very Anglocentric‚Äîit‚Äôs not the case in lots of other languages. This is hardly even a nit, since it‚Äôs obviously an English puzzle (just like it‚Äôs an American puzzle for ZEE)‚Äîbut maybe it would have been a nice educational opportunity in any case.
Also interesting to note that PAS means ‚Äústep‚Äù in French and was originally always used with ‚Äúne‚Äù, but gradually had the meaning of ‚Äúnot‚Äù all by itself.

Funny how Mary Poppins came up in the comments yesterday with PISH POSH and then in the puzzle today. Unlike Crystal it was the FIRST movie I Ever saw (I‚Äôm showing my age).

Anyways a fun puzzle and congrats all you NINERS fans‚Äîyou pulled it off when Carolina and Green Bay couldn‚Äôt.

This was fun! Thank you, Carolyn & Christina! Enjoyed the Wordplay, too, Crystal! Welcome.
Y‚Äôall stay warm and have a terrific Monday!

Another plug for voting for your favorite crossword puzzles of 2025, The Griddies! You all have nominated about 100 puzzles, showing what a good year 2025 was (for xwords, anyway). Here's the schedule moving forward: 1/11 - 1/16: Voting on First Round 1/18 - 1/25: Voting for Second (Final) Round 2/1: Announcement of winners & runners-up Here is the ballot: https://form.jotform.com/253465756808167 The ballot is easy to use. Vote for as many as five in each category; at the end, click "Submit" and you're all done, until the next round! Anyone can participate; the ballot has descriptions of the puzzles, but all the puzzles are easily accessed in archives: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/archive You'll see other announcements from Eric Hougland about this; if you have any questions, you can reply to this post or one of Eric's and someone will get back to you!

USEITORLOSEIT, Christina.

Bienvenue, Crystal--I can't imagine having a streak like that!

Our VHS renter had a sign that said DON'T rewind. When the tape has just been viewed it's hot and more vulnerable to damage, stretching.  They rewound them when they had cooled off.  Seemed like good advice. 

We still have a (weeded) library of VHS tapes, some we recorded and that aren't available anywhere else now.  I know people who tossed all of theirs and started over with CDs, then moved on to Blu-ray. Offends my antecedent Scotch-Irish, Welsh genes. (That squeak you heard was the tightening of my purse strings.)

First-round voting on the 2025 Griddy Awards is underway until 11:59 PM on January 16. You can find the ballot here: https://form.jotform.com/253465756808167 John Ezra, Marshall Walthew and I were pleased to see so many puzzles nominated. The ballot is lengthy ‚Äî I think there are about 100 puzzles across four categories. The puzzle descriptions are meant to simply remind you of the puzzle. We‚Äôve done our best to make sure that all the nominated puzzles are on the ballot. Our sincere apologies if you nominated a puzzle and it‚Äôs not on the ballot. If you vote, be sure you‚Äôll have time to finish the ballot. As far as I can tell, there‚Äôs no way to save your choices if you start the ballot and don‚Äôt submit it. However, you‚Äôll get an email with your votes and may be able to add votes if you‚Äôre under five in any category.‚Ä®‚Ä®You will get a somewhat generic error message if you try to select more than five puzzles in any category. The message pops up as soon as you choose a sixth puzzle, so it‚Äôs easily fixed by deselecting one of your choices. It‚Äôs actually a pretty good way of keeping you focused on the best of the best. And if you want to be sure you‚Äôve selected five, try choosing one more. At the end of the relevant section of the ballot, it will say ‚ÄúThe maximum number of selections allowed is 5.‚Äù We hope you‚Äôll find the ballot user-friendly. If you have any trouble with it, comment here. One of us will see it. Thanks for voting!
Nice Monday puzzle, had no problems with it. EASY PEASY LEMON SQUEEZY!

My local baker would always deliver his bread through my window, but it's being repaired right now. No pane, no grain!

(This one was sill-y, but I loaf it anyway.)
Welcome, Crystal. This is a lovely crowd until you make a mistake but once you‚Äôre in you‚Äôll be defended to the end.

I‚Äôm familiar with SAY IT DON‚ÄôT SPRAY IT from cartoons that I watched as a kid or that my kids watched. Like Bugs Bunny saying it to Daffy Duck PSYCH always makes me think of the TV show with James Roday and Dul√© Hill. It was one of my favorite series. https://youtu.be/bOGXyzXbYNo?si=zecaBdLYgidY1iD7 Fun Monday grid that brought back lots of childhood nostalgia. Thanks, Carolyn and Christina! Also wanted to thank Eric, John and Marshall for heading up the Griddies!
Just FYI, you don't need to rewind you DVDs!
Welcome, Crystal! That is one serious streak you‚Äôve got going there. Talk about street cred!
methinks this one will be a tougher-than-usual monday for solvers not of the north american persuasion...

I worked in a video store in the early ‚Äò90s, and people who returned video tapes without rewinding them were definitely unkind. We had a rewind machine for the noncompliant cassettes, but it was a pain to use and slowed down the reshelving process. Eventually, management imposed a rewind fee that reduced the problem, but never eliminated it. Some people just couldn‚Äôt be bothered.

I was out of the business by the time DVDs took over, but I suspect they made the employees much, much happier.

This one was a lot of fun, but I was distracted by my cat who has been going to the litter box about every 5 minutes the past couple days. I took him to the vet but they couldn‚Äôt find anything wrong, so now we‚Äôre just waiting for lab tests. I was doing this puzzle not fully focused and ended up spending quintuple my average time. It did help relax me though.

I found this too hard for Monday - my time says Tuesday. I didn't need any lookups in the end but there were more proper names than I like, especially on Monday.

What on Earth is a NITRO cold brew? I was a bit lost there. Of course I know W_NONA Ryder, but I can never remember if her name is spelled with a Y or an I. The Y version would fit nicely with R*y*der, wouldn't it?

NO PAIN NO GAIN annoyed me. I know it featuring in a crossword is not an endorsement of the sentiment but still... If you feel pain after exercising, you're doing things wrong - it was the first thing my physio told me when I finally went to see her after ignoring pain for too long. A personalized warmup and wind down routine takes care of such issues for me now.

I was having breakfast as I read about spraying while talking... Thanks üòê

Nice puzzle - I liked the clues and the fill was good. I only had the square in NI_RO and O_T left at the end since I'd never heard of either of the cold brew or the baseballer, but I got it in my first guess so I'll try to remember those.
Thanks Carolyn & Christina! (And Crystal - great trio! Reminds me of a group of students I once had in my class called Adriana, Andrea & Ariadna, who always sat together I'm sure just to confuse me...!)

My first answer for 6A Bird's dramatic dive was StOOP. That's the "dramatic dive" of a Peregrine Falcon, but easily corrected with the answer to 7D.  

Thanks for a fun Monday puzzle.

Chewy Monday üòÄ

47A at least the clue didn‚Äôt refer to Betamax ‚Ä¶ 

I know there are trivia my brain refuses to retain. Names of American university sports teams are very close to the top of the list‚Ä¶

Lovely Monday! Like others, TIL Shiso. I searched up some images, seems vaguely like mint.

It‚Äôs crazy to me that there are adults out there who have never heard of ‚Äùbe kind rewind.‚Äù I continue to struggle with the 1945 puzzle (almost 6 hours‚Ä¶) and I like to think that this is why. Maybe a Chinese Buffalo nut was slang for a costume party or something. 

The app forced me to update - how do you see recent puzzles now?

Have a great week everyone ‚ù§Ô∏è
Welcome Crystal and congrats on your streak. And congrats and thanks to Carolyn and Christina for a fun puzzle.
That felt like it took aaaaages but I was faster than my average. Weird.
I resumed my subscription last week, only to find Deb has left the column. My monday crosswords feel lonesome without her. That said, lovely crossword today; felt a bit tricky

I think this crossword was easier for Gen Z, because I managed to solve quicker than my average!

I really enjoyed todays puzzle :)
Ouch, SAY IT, DON'T SPRAY IT gave me a bit of a wrench. I heard that in the 1950s! I know, I know, it's gross to be spat upon, but in defense of the spitters, I must say that they can't help it.

The Mary Poppins quote is clearly from the movie. The original character from the books would never have said it! Both are fun characters and stories but completely different aside from featuring a mysterious nanny and her charges.

There is an art to Monday cluing that‚Äôs hard to nail.  You want it easy but not embarrassingly easy overall.  I think C&C nailed it.  

Look at the first two clues ‚Äì [Intimidate, with ‚Äúout‚Äù] for PSYCHE, and [Bird‚Äôs dramatic dive] for SWOOP.  Your mileage may vary, but I had to think a moment before getting the latter, and I needed a cross or two for the former.  There is enough of this type cluing -- requiring thought, but not end-of-week thought -- to make the fill-in involving.

Add to that a theme with fun rhymes and fun answers to guess at with as few crosses as possible, and this puzzle felt like a paragon Monday.

Oh, and extra credit for [Put in a good word, perhaps?] for EDIT.  Here‚Äôs a word appearing more than 700 times in the NYT puzzle, and you‚Äôd think the well would have run dry on new clues.  But this one is not only terrific, it‚Äôs a debut.  Mwah!

A lovely collab, Carolyn and Christina.  Thank you both, and please consider doing more together ‚Äì go with the flow!

Despite a few just-slightly-trickier clues, it‚Äôs nice to see the constructors followed the rhyming pleas of Monday solvers:

USE A WORD THAT WE‚ÄôVE HEARD!



fun one

My survey of Songs Based on Yo-yo Tricks continues: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K0HSD_i2DvA&list=RDK0HSD_i2DvA&start_radio=1 (Check out those costumes--they're scary good!) Overheard on the weight room floor of Planet Ctenophore: "Dude, No brain, no pain!" The word "pas" in French can have so many different meanings, some of them contranyms, all of them related etymologically. It's a cold, snowy morning up here in Lewistonia--the lake is iced over, the landscape has a sad and frozen character: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2tVtd-16w2U&list=RD2tVtd-16w2U&start_radio=1

Nice Monday puzzle. A lot of things not coming to me just from the clues but had fun working it all out from the crosses. And.. a couple of odd puzzle finds today: A Wednesday from April 3, 1996 by Matt Gaffney. And.. a Tuesday from October 28, 2003 by Brendan Emmett Quigley. The Gaffney puzzle had 3 across theme answers all straightforwardly clued: VIDKUNQUISLING JUDASISCARIOT BENEDICTARNOLD And.. the Quigley puzzle had 3 down theme answers. Exactly the same ones that were in the Gaffney puzzle. Hmmm... can't help but wonder. Here are those links: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/3/1996&g=20&d=A https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/28/2003&g=14&d=D I'm done. .....

"Swoop" is the mascot of Eastern Michigan University, where you think the sports teams would be the Emus, but no, they're the Eagles. (Which is still better than their old name, the Normalites.) I hear Swoop has a brother in Philadelphia, and a cousin in Utah. Pish!

I'm on my mid-winter getaway in Northern Lower Michigan, and this area is the unique breeding grounds of the federally protected Kirtland's warbler. It's a Big Deal up here: Mio, Michigan, has a statue of one in front of the Oscoda County courthouse (not life-sized, of course).  (Presently, the Kirtland's warblers all in the Bahamas. They sent a postcard.)

The local vocational college is Kirtland Community College, home of the Firebirds. I suppose "the Fighting Warblers" doesn't sound intimidating enough.

Cute puzzle idea.  Two of the rhyming phrases (PAIN and REWIND) were extremely familiar, whereas SNOOZE rang a vague bell and the SPRAY one was new to me.

I like sushi and order it often.  I've never heard of SHISO.  No wonder Rex made it his word of the day.  It looks like it's there to decorate the plate and not to be eaten.  I'm only interested in sushi I can eat.

A word about IODINE.  I remember it from my childhood.  It hurt horribly.  Then they invented mercurochrome and merthiolate as substitutes and I was happy.  Then they discovered that both substitutes were dangerous and I'm not quite sure what they're using now.  Anyone who knows -- please tell me, but only if it doesn't hurt.

Fair warning: if I see INSPO one more time, I'm going to scream.

I just now successfully completed the Sunday crossword. Caitlin failed to mention that the PHI character Œ¶ (Alt 232 on Windows keyboard) was an acceptable entry for the rebus square; I had my doubts, but I tried it, and it worked. I tried to scan the 808 comments to see if anyone else completed the puzzle the same way, but it did not turn up anything.  Anyone else use Œ¶ to complete the puzzle yesterday?

Hoo, boy.  It's been a long while since somebody looked into a First Aid kit!  Wound care (other than washing thoroughly) is quite different these days, whether due to injury or surgery.  IODINE is a necessary element in diet (see "iodized salt") but not--repeat NOT--recommended on a boo-boo.

And then there is the VERY suspect clue at 33D.  The level of ignorance is a little scary.  In the first place, AMNIOcentesis is not routinely done.  For example, my OB was preparing to perform this to be sure the fetus had sufficiently developed lungs, because I had been hospitalized with pre-eclampsia; however, there was so little room for a needle that he backed off.  The little rascal had also managed to turn completely and was in "frank breech position."  (Yes, it was PhysDau, starting her brilliant career early with a c-sec.)  The OTHER reason for AMNIOcentesis is to allow for genetic testing, which opens a controversial topic the EDITor may have been attempting to avoid with the "second trimester" business.  AMNIO is done during the first trimester.

YOU SNOOZE YOU LOSE is very good advice. There certainly have been times that I missed out on something because I didn‚Äôt act quickly enough. 

Good advice that I got from my mother was ‚ÄúDress for success‚Äù, although she didn‚Äôt use those rhyming words. When I first started working she said to always dress professionally as you never knew who you would meet that day. That advice served me very well in my career. It doesn't seem to matter much nowadays, but for my generation it did.  Thanks, Mom.

TIL SHISO, and I see I'm not the only one.

I've been to a good number of Sushi restaurants, and I've never seen SHISO on a sushi platter.  Occasionally a banana leaf, occasionally fake, plastic grass (with supermarket sushi), but never (so far as I know) SHISO.

Live and learn.  I hope to able to try it one day.

Honestly, I usually look to a Monday puzzle without a lot of enthusiasm, as the challenge is generally a let down after the Thursday-Sunday workouts. This is not a criticism of Monday constructors‚Ä¶they have their assignment and do it well in the main‚Ä¶but Monday puzzles aren‚Äôt Sunday puzzles. 

I say all this as context for my appreciation of the puzzle, which was a relative workout for the day of the week.
Genuinely curious ‚Ä¶ how does one get a streak of 3060 after only eight years?

Wow, that column photo is so great, it's unnerving.
Yikes, an orca and an eyeball.

Welcome, Crystal!
I still have a VHS rewinding machine. Next to boxes of VHS tapes in my garage. Miss those days.

Cherry wood is scary good.

When an onion you seek, don't take a leek.

If a tree falls in the forest, the nearest person may soon be the sorest. (some people end this with "shortest")

Nothing's as therapeutical as reveling in a musical. (Andrzej taught me that one.)

Ice cream, you scream, we all scream because we're annoying little brats. (Andrzej again. Apparently that rhymes in Polish.)

One should never dance afore removing one's pants. (Okay, that's enough wisdom from Andrzej for now.)

Speak softly and reek awfully.

There's nothing absurd about having a best friend who's a cheese curd.

We watch a lot of NHK cooking shows so SHISO was a gimmie.  Attended an eastern PA ag college where I learned the true meaning of 18A: The prof was beloved but you did not want to sit in the front of the class.  Lesson learned. 

A terrific Monday.  Many thanks.
Fun and breezy start to the week

What a fun Monday puzzle and a fine themed collaboration from Carolyn and Christina! Welcome, Crystal, and thanks for the nice Wordplay column. You should definitely see the original MARY POPPINS sometime soon!

Happy Monday, everyone!

Welcome, Crystal!  

3060 is impressive.   

I think you will find this a lively and fun place to be.  Please drop into the chat from time to time - it's always great to hear from Wordplay columnists and constructors!

I loved this puzzle but didn‚Äôt get the happy music upon completion. I found my error at 71A: SEdTO‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt believe I entered ZEd instead of ZEE at 65D. I‚Äôm always careful on theatre and centre and favour and colour, etc‚Ä¶ this one shouldn‚Äôt have tripped me up at all! And yet! :)
Great puzzle! Thanks!

I am having a problem with Wordle.  I thought that Deb (or someone) had provided an email address for crossword bug problems, but I can't find it.

If anyone knows this, please let me know.

Bonnie
Delightful!!

A nice, crunchy Monday. I see I‚Äôm in good company with the TIL SHISO. I still don‚Äôt know what it actually is; leaf? Plant? Seaweed?

Enjoyed the rhyming theme, yes the video one did take me right back to Friday nights at blockbuster. Nice.

I love a chewy Monday. Simple enough to finish without looking anything up; yet some answers that I had to think about or get via crosses. Very enjoyable; a great collaboration!

Did you remember to do the midi today? Another reason to love Mondays! Three crosswords, Maxi, Midi, and Mini! Plus, Connections and Worldle went easily for me today. Here's hoping Monday at the ER will go easily for me as well. Usually, Monday and Friday are the busiest days in our ER, which makes them go fast. We are seeing so much flu, and this is a bad flu. It's not too late to get a flu shot!
A friend with weed, is a friend indeed.

This is a Monday puzzle and I always fly through Monday puzzles. But today, I'm way out of my solve time. I'm brain deficient after having a poor night's sleep. So there's that. But the thing is I've made a mistake somewhere and I cannot find it. I've poured over the puzzle several times and I came here thinking I'd find a kindred spirit. I'm feeling rather stubborn about doing a reveal on a Monday puzzle. So If anyone has an idea please ring in.  Thank you.
A lovely and fun way to start the crossword week. Welcome Crystal! I felt similarly wrt 90s nostalgia in this one, which is always welcome imo. Happy Monday all!

Here‚Äôs today‚Äôs poem (as usual a/ is the across clues; d/ is down clues and a/ is answers:

on matters of birds

a/ birds greeting 
birds in the machinery 
of song
circulates
reddish leaf to reddish brown
d/ my my
so fun to feather around
every puffy one of them 
a/ my my
my my

I also enjoyed the rhyming, although my memory has the VHS phrase as, ‚ÄúBE KIND [please] REWIND.‚Äù 

In fairness, I spent a lot more time growing up in local rental stores than Blockbuster so maybe it just varied across the shops. Nice puzzle!

crystal:

How far back should I start doing early week puzzles?

This is the second time I've been knocked out of the air by a clue like "a bird's dramatic dive".   I always use "stoop" unstead of "swoop".   To me, a swoop implies a dive...for sure...with a curved movement somewhere in the execution.   I've seen lots of birds swoop...but I've only seen one bird stoop.  It was a falcon...and dove on a pigeon in flight...starting high, high above it's target.  The falcon folded its wings tight against  its body and dropped like a stone...straight down....accelerating all the way and hit the pigeon in an explosion of feathers...and followed the prey's fall to the ground.  That, my fellow crossworders was dramatic.  Swoops are pretty.  Stoops are breathtaking.
GOD THIS WAS SO TOUGH

SAYITDONTSPRAYIT took me back about 60 years or so to the playgrounds of my childhood, where that and other such pithy utterances were the cornerstones of our daily interactions.  So often I find the crossword functioning like Proust‚Äôs madeleine to involuntarily recapture my past.
That was a fun Monday puzzle!!  A++
This puzzle just suddenly reminded of this: "Ladies and gentlemen, take my advice. Pull down your pants and slide on the ice." https://youtu.be/cxQOfyp6E5o?si=MY5BCDM6sH4P0Lqm Paging Dr Freud!

Neat puzzle. Didn't really care much about the theme, but the puzzle wasn't bad.  I put IDY instead of ILY; the reason why I realized my mistake was that I encountered articles explaining the difference between this and "Devil Horns." Whoops! Anyways, see ya'll tomorrow hopefully! :)




(Today was also my first NYT puzzle done without Google, so that's nice! ü•≥)

Late puzzle find. A Sunday from November 1, 1970 by A.J. Santora with the title: "Squarely figured." This one had rebus squares which were numerals. Some sample answers: (10)DOWNINGSTREET (40)WINKS (80)DAYS (76)TROMBONES ROUTE(66) And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/1/1970&g=76&d=D ...
FUN puzzle! Where's Sam Corbin???
This puzzle took me 6:10 longer than my average, and I am very happy about it. That was an elegant one! Monday, but make it classy.
How do I update my email? My new email is msk566@protonmail.com.

As I sit here at my desk, still 2 hours from dawn, watching it sleet outside my window, I‚Äôm humming my new favorite song, the earworm courtesy of the [‚ÄúHeyo!‚Äù] clue. Only the one I‚Äôm humming‚Äîyes, yes, Se√±or Gato, I know singing disturbs cats, but your lying on my keyboard (so much for having a LAPCAT) isn‚Äôt exactly conducive to my working, now is it. Anyhow, as I was saying, the song I‚Äôm humming has ‚Äúheyo‚Äù spelled a little differently: it goes, ‚ÄúHejo, guter alter Mond,‚Äù and it‚Äôs a snowshoeing song my nieces thrice removed infected me with over the Christmas break as we trekked through Bergen‚Äôs Seven Mountains (of which there aren‚Äôt seven; but I digress). It‚Äôs‚Ä¶ technically a kids‚Äô song? But I loved belting it out so much, even though I was admonished by my younger niece repeatedly‚Äîand with overt frustration‚Äîthat both my r‚Äôs and my vowels are hopelessly substandard. So, hejo to you all on this wintry Tuesday morning, and here goes: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=e691kkCRfK8

I‚Äôm late coming back here (Monday was an interesting day), but if you‚Äôve never seen the 2008 movie BE KIND REWIND, my memory of it is that it is very funny. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0799934/?ref_=ext_shr_imdbWS

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Patient watchers]
[Poles can be found next to them]


NURSES
CZECHS
@Petrol oh yes, it‚Äôs a favorite of sassy kids. The full version is, ‚ÄúSAYITDONTSPRAYIT, I want the news not the weather‚Äù

@Petrol

Oh yes, definitely! I thought it about someone just a day or two ago, but I did refrain from saying it since I'm no longer a child and the person wasn't someone I thought would think it was funny. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

@Petrol

I didn‚Äôt find it cute as I‚Äôve only heard it towards someone with a speech impediment or braces. It was used to make fun of them.

@Elizabeth Connors
Some people just spit when they talk. Children often lack the boundaries to just take a step back

@Petrol,

It was definitely said back in the day, when someone would get you a little wet while they were talking. It was a clever witticism, always funny, even to the original speaker.

@Petrol

Depends. It was a common witticism among pre-teens, back when I was one of them. I haven‚Äôt heard it said since I reached adulthood, and I don‚Äôt know if kids still say it. You‚Äôd have to ask one of them.

@Elizabeth Connors

Ohhh, really !?  would hate it if that had been my experience!! I never knew it as a form of mockery about a speech impediment or anything....  My main recollection of it was students who sat in the front row of a particular class in high school, or maybe it was Junior high, but the teacher was known for projecting spitile as he excitedly lectured.

Good morning Valerie,

When the "SAY IT ..." answer came to mind, I immediately thought that I hadn't heard that saying since grammar school in the 1970's.  Then "BE KIND..." brought me back to the Blockbuster Store visits in the 1990's.  Who knew the crossword could inspire a trip down memory lane!

@Kathryn
I thought about how the younger generation who grew up with only digital streaming might not get BE KIND REWIND, but it was a fun trip for me. I love how crosswords can spark old memories and also introduce things that are new to me. Happy Monday!

@Valerie
They might not get SAY IT/SPRAY IT because they are so rarely in the same room with each other any more.

@Dale M
Sad, but true!  Even making an actual phone call vs text or email, seems a bygone concept. I have a granddaughter in college who consults me on all all things ‚Äúold school,‚Äù like how to cash a paper check or mail a letter, which I guess are also things they rarely need to do these days.
@Mango I normally only come to the comments to say how much I disliked a puzzle so trying something new here. Lol.

@HeathieJ

I can only get good mangos certain times of the year. I‚Äôm surprised you get them year-round.

@Elizabeth Connors

Believe it or not, the best ones we get in this area are at Aldi! 

But my husband, who's from a little tropical island in the Caribbean, is a master at picking them out. And if they're not going to be any good, he leaves them.  There are mango less weeks, but their fewer and far between. 

We also have a tropical store nearby that has good ones, if nothing else.

@Elizabeth Connors

But also, we like them at different stages of ripeness, that we both have a favorite, which is more full, but there are various things we can use them for in different ways we can use them depending on where they are on the scale.

@HeathieJ

My local Krogers known as Jewel does have a substandard produce department. I‚Äôm going to try one of the independent stores this week.

@The X-Phile

Nothing else, and preferably w/out a bandage (which can be really inconvenient.)  Those were the "discharge instructions" after the last few squamous-cell carcinoma surgeries I had.  The nurse said, "There are just too many people who are allergic."

@Mean Old Lady

Good morning MOL. (I have such a hard time thinking of you as "mean")!

I had an amnio (dear lord, the size of that needle!) to see if my baby had spina bifida, due to a misdirection from my mother-in-law, who described one of her babies as having an opening on his skull... you don't really need the details, but that child, and several others, didn't survive. She buried 4 before adopting, and then having my husband. She convinced herself that we were doing the AMNIO to find out if the baby was gay (seriously) because my husband's brother had just come out to us. That's how we found out he was adopted. Well, we all knew he was; it was quite obvious. But they never discussed it with him. Sad all around; he died without ever being told. 

All this to say, I agree, it is far from a routine test. Especially now... mine was 46 years ago. Today, you can tell so much from an ultrasound. For instance, my granddaughter had a kidney condition that would require surgery at the age of six months. But it was discovered a few weeks before birth, through routine ultrasound. So much safer than an amnio!

@Mean Old Lady

I don‚Äôt understand. It didn‚Äôt say that amniocentesis is routinely done, it just says if it is done it is done by an OB and that it is usually done in the 2nd trimester. Seems accurate to me. I don‚Äôt think the clue is going to prompt anyone to get an unnecessary amino, at least I hope not.

@SP
The 'second trimester' is not accurate.  It may be deliberately misleading.  As the post from Marlene describes, AMNIO can detect some abnormalities ...and parents then face a decision.  It is not without risk to the pregnancy.  The concern is not "prompting someone to get a procedure" --it is not up to the patient--it is the misleading info about the timing.

I never even considered StOOP, but I like it. More dramatic, certainly, especially f you've ever seen an osprey catch a fish.

@Grant    That is a great sight too!  In northcentral PA where I live, the local trout stream (a small river, really) has a resident population of both ospreys and bald eagles.  The eagles are thieves mostly.  They wait for ospreys to depart with their catch...then dive on them causing the ospreys to drop their fish.  The eagles then lunch as a group.  Don't know why politics come to mind when I see that happen.
